questions.text: Identify the primary air pollutants among the following options: Carbon Monoxide (CO) Methane (CH4) Sulfur Dioxide (SO2) Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2) Ozone (O3) Lead (Pb)
questions.explanation:
Primary

Secondary
  • Carbon Monoxide (CO)
  • Sulfur Dioxide (SO₂)
  • Nitrogen Oxides (NOₓ)
  • Particulate Matter (PM₁₀, PM₂.₅)
  • Volatile Organic Compounds
  • Lead (Pb)
  • Ozone (O₃)
  • Methane (CH4)
  • Sulfates
  • Nitrates
  • Secondary Particulate Matter

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator of air pollution?
questions.explanation:
Sulphur Dioxide (SO2)
  • A gas emitted from burning fossil fuels and industrial processes; causes respiratory problems and acid rain.
  • Most important indicator of air pollution.

Soiling Index
  • Measures the accumulation of particulate matter (dirt) on surfaces.
  • Specific amount of air is filtered through a filter paper and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter.

Grit and Dust Measurement
  • Quantifies the concentration of dust, grit deposits and small particulate matter present in the air.

Coefficient of Haze
  • Measures smoke and other aerosols in air.

Air Pollution Index (API)
  • Composite measure of overall air quality based on concentrations of various pollutants.

Category

0-50

Good

51-100

301-400

questions.text: Match the following question Indoor Air Pollutants and their Sources: Pollutant Source 1. Polyaromatic hydrocarbons a. Destruction of construction materials 2. Asbestos b. Adhesives, Solvents and Aerosol sprays 3. Aldehydes c. Fuel consumption 4. Benzene d. Furnishings and Construction materials
questions.explanation:
Source

Pollutant

Fuel consumption

Carbon monoxide, Polyaromatic hydrocarbons, Nitrogen oxides

Tobacco consumption

Carbon monoxide, Polyaromatic hydrocarbons

Coal combustion

Sulphur oxides, arsenic, and fluorine

Furnishings, construction materials, cooking

Aldehydes

Remodelling and destruction of construction materials

Asbestos

Remodelling/demolition of painted surfaces, leaded fuels, smelting

Lead

Building and construction materials

Radon

Adhesives, solvents, aerosol sprays, resin products

Organic vapours like benzene, toluene

Incineration, coal burning, petroleum burning

Hydrocarbons

questions.text: Which of the following is best measured by McArdle's Index?
questions.explanation:
Cooling Power of air (Option A)
  • Determines the capacity of the atmosphere to dissipate the metabolite heat generated by humans.
  • Includes 3 components: Air temperature, Air humidity and low air velocity.
  • Measured by a Kata thermometer.

Heat Stress Index (Option B)
  • The ratio of evaporation required to maintain heat balance to maximum evaporation maintained in a particular environment is expressed as a percentage.
  • Related to body sweating.
  • It ranges from 0 to 100.
    • Severe heat strain: 40 to 60
    • Very severe heat strain: 70 to 90
    • The upper limit of heat tolerance: 100.

Effective Temperature
  • Measures heat stress index.
  • This includes air temperature, air humidity, and airflow/air velocity and cooling power of air

Corrected effective temperature (Option D)
  • A better indicator of air comfort than effective temperature.
  • Includes 4 components: Air temperature, air humidity, air velocity, Mean radiant heat ( i.e Effective temperature+ mean radiant heat)
  • A Globe thermometer is an instrument used to measure this.

questions.text: What is the instrument's name, shown below, for measuring low air velocity?
questions.explanation:
Kata thermometer:

 
  • Identification: It has a narrow and thin bulb that is red-coloured.
  • Used to measure
    • Low air velocity.
    • Cooling power of air (rarely) as it does not provide reliable estimates.
  • The cooling power of air is an indicator of air comfort.
  • A dry Kata reading of more than 6 and a wet Kata reading of more than 20 indicate thermal comfort.

 

Globe thermometer:

 
  • Identification: A thick and wide bulb is present.
  • Used to measure corrected effective temperature or radiant heat.

Wet bulb hygrometer:

  • Used to measure the relative humidity of the atmosphere.

 

Anemometer:

  • Used to measure air velocity in the early days.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the following device are not true? It measures radiant heat flux. It is used to assess thermal comfort in indoor environments. It measures a lower temperature than the ordinary air temperature It measures air temperature directly. It is not used to measure the cooling power of air.
questions.explanation:
Air quality measurement

Globe thermometer
  • Thick, wide and hollow copper bulb coated with matt black paint.
  • Used to measure corrected effective temperature or mean radiant heat (convection/ transferred heat). (STATEMENT 1)
  • While the globe thermometer does measure a component of air temperature, it primarily measures the mean radiant temperature, which is a combined effect of air temperature, radiant heat, and air movement (Statment 4).
  • Registers higher temperature than the ordinary air temperature (STATEMENT 3)
  • Influenced by air movement velocity and temperature
  • A wet globe thermometer consists of a blackened copper sphere completely covered with wet black cloth that exchanges heat by conduction, convection, evaporation and radiation (like sweating).

questions.text: All of the following instruments can be used to measure air humidity except?
questions.explanation:
Air humidity measuring instruments
  1. Hygrometer
  1. Sling psychrometer

1. Wet and dry thermometers are mounted side by side
  1. Assman psychrometer

1. Can be used even in strong sunshine
  1. Dry and wet bulb hygrometer

1. Most widely used

2. Same readings in both (dry and wet) bulbs indicate 100 per cent saturation with moisture

questions.text: Which of the following is true about global warming?

options.label: A
options.text: It is primarily caused by increased solar radiation.

options.label: B
options.text: Paris Agreement aimed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in developed countries

options.label: C
options.text: Kyoto Protocol called for a 50% reduction in greenhouse emissions.

options.label: D
options.text: Water vapour is one of the important greenhouse gases.

questions.correct_answer: D. Water vapour is one of the important greenhouse gases.

questions.text: Match the loudness of noise in decibels (dB) with their corresponding situation. 1. 60 dB a. Threshold of hearing damage 2. 85 dB b. Rupture of tympanic membrane 3. 160 dB c. Permanent deafness 4. 100 dB d. Normal conversation
questions.explanation:
Situation

Loudness (dB)

1. Whispering

20 to 30 dB.

2. Quiet library

40 dB.

2. Normal conversation

60 to 65 dB.

3. Heavy street traffic

60 to 80 dB.

4. Tolerable daily exposure/ threshold to noise without hearing damage

85 dB.

5. Auditory fatigue

90 dB.

6. Permanent deafness (repeated or continuous exposure to noise)

Around 100 dB

7. Boiler factories

120 dB.

8. Noise threshold for pain

140 dB.

9. Jet take-off

150 dB

10. Rupture of tympanic membrane

Above 160 dB.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a type of mechanical ventilation?
questions.explanation:
Types of Ventilation

Natural (Option B, C and D)

Mechanical (Option A )

1. Wind:

  • Perflation: wind blows through a room
  • Aspiration: wind bypasses and exerts a suction
  • Cross-ventilation.

2. Diffusion: Air passes through small openings

3. Temperature Inequality: Air movement from high to low density due to temperature difference.

1. Exhaust: air is extracted outside by exhaust fans

2. Plenum: fresh air blown inside by centrifugal fans

3. Balanced: Combination of exhaust and plenum

4. Air conditioning: control of all air factors affecting physical and chemical conditions of the atmosphere

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary use of this instrument?

options.label: B
options.text: Measuring occupational noise exposure over a period of time

options.label: C
options.text: Measuring the intensity of sound in dB

questions.correct_answer: B. Measuring occupational noise exposure over a period of time
questions.explanation:
Instrument

Uses

1. Noise dosimeter (OPTION B)
  • Sound level meter.
  • To measure noise exposure of a person over a period of time
  • Eg: Occupational exposure

2. Audiometer (OPTION D)
  • Used for evaluation of hearing ability

3. Hand-held microphone (OPTION C)
  • To measure the intensity of sound in dB

4. Octave band analyser (OPTION A)
  • To measure sound in octave bands
  • Reflects sound spectrum ranging from low-pitched to high-pitched frequencies.

questions.explanation:
PARAMETER

DESCRIPTION

UNIT OF MEASUREMENT

Luminous intensity

Brightness of a light source

Candela

Luminous flux

Light flow

Lumen (option A)

Illumination/illuminance

Measure of light reaching a surface

Lux (option B)

Brightness/luminance

Measure of light reflected from a surface

Lambert (option D)

Daylight measure

Intensity of daylight illumination

Daylight factor

questions.text: Identify the correct statements regarding ideal housing standards. Built-up area of houses should not exceed 2/3rd in urban areas Roof of a house should be at least 10 meters in height Window area should be at least 1/5th of the floor area Cattle sheds should be at least 25 feet from the housing area Door and window should be at least 2/5th of the floor area
Which of the following is not considered overcrowding?

options.label: B
options.text: 1 person living in a floor space of 65 sq.ft.

options.label: C
options.text: 2 persons aged 7 of opposite gender in the same room

options.label: D
options.text: A child aged 8 years living in a floor space of 45 sq.ft.

questions.correct_answer: C. 2 persons aged 7 of opposite gender in the same room
questions.explanation:
Persons Per Room

Floor Space (1 sq.m. = 10 sq.ft.)
  • 1 room - 2 persons
  • 2 rooms - 3 persons
  • 3 rooms - 5 persons (option A)
  • 4 rooms - 7 persons
  • 5 or more rooms - 10 persons (2 per each room)
  • Not recommended: <50 sq.ft.
  • ½ person : 50-70 sq. ft. (option D)
  • 1 person: 70-90 sq. ft. (option B)
  • 1 ½ persons: 90-100 sq. ft.
  • 2 persons : >110 sq. ft.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male who wants to set up a radio diagnostic centre consults you regarding the possible health hazards his radio technicians might face. What is the ideal thickness of lead aprons you advise him to provide his employees that should prevent the employees from radiation hazards?
questions.explanation:
RADIATION DOSE

BIOLOGICAL EFFECTS

<5 rad
  • No adverse effects
 

5-150 rad
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Mild haematological changes
 

150-1100 rad
  • Bone marrow failure (anaemia, infections, bleeding tendency - might require bone marrow transplantation), death occur in years.
 

1100-2000 rad
  • Gastrointestinal destruction in addition (death almost always occurs in a few weeks)

>2000 rad
  • Muscle and brain damage (death occurs in days)
